Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move

Message.Msg: It's there, but you have to know how to look for it. It's not on the income statement. It's on the balance sheet. Cash is increased. The proceeds from the cash increases paid in capital in excess of par. You have to look at the retained earnings statement, which is usually in a footnote. That's where much of the $1 Billion increase in capital surplus may have come from. One of the reasons this is a popular technique for high tech companies (and others) to raise cash is that it is not required to be specifically disclosed by the SEC or by GAAP. Could AMZN raise $1 Billion from selling out of the market puts? YES, easily. The market capitalization of AMZN is about $120 billion and the stock trades over a million shares a day. AMZN has 454 million shares outstanding. The January 2014 200 puts sell for about $10, $1000 per 100 shares. Buying a million shares in the market today would cost $265 million. Selling away the right to have 1 million shares put to you at $200 a share would give you $10 million. If forced to buy the shares, the cost would be $210 million, instead of $265 million today. Most of the time out of the money puts expire worthless, so this could be done over and over. AMZN would not be doing this on an options exchange, though, but in an OTC transaction with a trading desk of an investment bank.

Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move

Message.Msg: NO, AMZN is not speculating in its own stock. This technique of raising cash is done by tens of high tech firms. Its SOP.

Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move

Message.Msg: Please let me know if I am interpreting your comment correctly. I think your meaning is that major mutual fund managers like Fidelity have been selling publicly traded options, both puts and calls, over the past four years. They have sold out of the money puts with great success against passive income generators with thin trading volumes (low float) as the "pigz" moved up in price 6 times above their price at the bottom. They have made huge profits selling weekly puts and calls, most of which expire worthless, to speculators. When some of their holdings look like they will fall in price, they have profitably closed out their positions by buying back the naked puts they sold, sold covered calls against their stock, and opened new positions by buying naked puts sold to them by individual investors on options exchanges. Then, they bought back their covered calls at a profit, sold their stock at a profit, and because of the drop in price caused by the sale of their stock, sold the puts at a huge profit. Fidelity may have done all that with their investments/speculation in GMCR and NFLX. By pigz, do you mean utilities, master limited partnerships, and real estate investment trusts? ======================================================== Note that many mutual funds are structured so that the fund manager may earn revenue from stocks held in the fund by using derivatives and by loaning out the stock for short selling. The profits from those transactions belong ONLY to the fund manager, not to the mutual fund shareholders, unless the mutual fund indenture specifically states that such profits are to go to mutual fund shareholders. In most funds, in return for being allowed to make those profits, the mutual fund manager is obligated to indemnify the fund for losses from derivatives trading and from stock lending.

Topic.Title: Another Barron's article mentions AMZN as a top holding of the fund manager: at the bottom as well, bullish in Barron's this weekend.

Message.Msg: Price: The way to #$%$ if capital investments are performing is not to look for a small increase in gross margin. It is to evaluate whether the ROIC is increasing significantly over time. For Amazon, it is dropping and hard. Why? Because Amazon makes less net profit per item sold on 3P versus 1P, yet is adding roughly the same amount of incremental CapEx to service FBA as it would have to internally (actually more, due to inventory optimization theory, but that is for another time...). Looking at gross margins including service revenues when those service revenues drive fulfillment costs but have no cost of product simply isn't intellectually honest. When including fulfillment, the improvement is much smaller (rather than an increase of 3.5%, it would be an increase of 2.4%. Net operating margins are still just 2.2% from 1.7%. Anchor on those numbers are let's hear all the analysts raving about higher margins at 2.2%... The other laughable claim is the massive savings in shipping cost. It isn't happening. Gross shipping cost as a % of revenue have actually increased to 8.45% from 8.41%. Net shipping cost have declined slightly to 4.5% of sales from 5.4% of sales because of revenue transfer from Prime in 2012 that didn't happen in 2011... The gross line is the one that cannot be manipulated (given Amazon's opacity, no one knows how it splits revenue recognition from Prime as far as I can tell). Just wait for the rest of the year to play out and follow these lines... They will get more interesting as time passes. Despite the rhetoric, the regional buildout is not providing the claimed leverage (fulfillment is GROWING as a % of net sales and GROSS shipping is also GROWING as a % of net sales).

Topic.Title: Morgan Stanley Issues $16MM of Securities that Bet on Amazon Move

Big short option strikes are like magnets... given the way short gamma affects trader behavior. But the deal is too small to matter given the daily volume of AMZN shares.

Topic.Title: Another Barron's article mentions AMZN as a top holding of the fund manager: at the bottom as well, bullish in Barron's this weekend.

Message.Msg: Nota bene: 1) All prime customers are not created equal. They are not equally profitable. A great analyst would ask how revenue (better yet incremental profit) per Prime customer is changing over time and ask for a cohort analysis of Prime customers as well... Mark this post. This will prove to be a real issue over the next few years... 2) Amazon's GROSS shipping cost as a percent of total revenues will grow this year rather than shrink and its net shipping cost will grow as a % of revenue versus Q4... If you work bottom up, you will see why... 3) Most importantly, the gross margin comp is going to get a lot harder next quarter and throughout the year. While GM sucked in Q42011, it was 24.8% for all of FY 2012... In other words, Q4 did not have magically improved margins from the rest of the year. Q4 was marginally better than the rest of the year. This was simply the one YOY comp that analysts could push to continue the pump and dump... The MM's can keep scaling options and playing financial games, but Amazon is up against fundamental economic constraints that are going to expose all the failings of the business model in 2013. Those who keep playing the game are going to have A LOT of explaining to do, because the flaws in Amazon's economic model are knowable with good DD, even with Amazon's amazing opacity. I am honestly FLOORED that large institutional holders allow Amazon to hide or omit material information (such as sales intensity in states where collecting tax versus those where it is not). I would think that responsible investors would demand vastly more transparency before accumulating a stock trading at north of 30X operating cash flow (operating cash flow which, by the way, only grew 7% in 2012, despite all the hype)... Unlike Bruce, large institutions cannot get out of their position without moving the market. The clock is running out of the scam. Margin comps will be much higher next quarter... They are running out of misplaced metrics to anchor people on... Have a good weekend...

Topic.Title: Another Barron's article mentions AMZN as a top holding of the fund manager: at the bottom as well, bullish in Barron's this weekend.

Message.Msg: Yeah, the math will work even better on that than Amazon's existing business... What everyone misses when talking about NG engines is the upfront ENERGY investment required in replacing fleets. UPS and FedEx should raise prices on Amazon to much higher levels. Amazon has ZERO choice but to use them (or risk its brand with the USPS...), but is trying to disintermediate them over the longer term. With retail matching prices, Amazon simply cannot afford delivery risk... Let Amazon raise $20B to build out its own delivery fleet.... I'm gonna enjoy watching Amazon get slammed from all sides. That's the problem with lack of focus and a zero profit strategy. It makes everyone your competitor or enemy...

Topic.Title: Welcome to new shorts here.

Message.Msg: Geege, You must be aware that for every new share shorted, an additional long share is "created". For each short share, two people will show a long position in their account for that share; the person from whom the share was borrowed (to lend to the short seller) and the person who bought the share from the short seller. Therefore, two people think they own that share, and each brokerage account will reflect that they own the share. Therefore, for each shorted share, there are two potential share owners (who could decide to sell). Therefore a squeeze is just as likely to occur in either direction, depending on who has the upper hand that day.
